summary: apoD has been characterized as a 29-kDa secreted glycoprotein. it is a member of the family of lipocalins responsible for the binding and transport of small lipophilic molecules. it is known to bind more specifically to arachidonic acid (AA),2 progesterone, and sphingomyelin. neuronal overexpression of apoD in transgenic mice led to increased resistance to oxidative stress (25) and inflammation (26). apoD deletion in mice resulted in decreased resistance and survival in response to oxidative stress in the brain (25). apoD could specifically prevent lipid peroxidation through a that BSG is widely expressed in many tissues, including in the brain (39, 48–50) in the brain, BSG is strongly expressed in the limbic system (including the hippocampus, olfactory system), cortex, and cerebellum (51). elevated BSG expression enhances tumor invasion by stimulating the secretion of multiple matrix metalloproteinases. the high glycosylated form of BSG, HG-BSG, is presumed to be a precursor for HG-BSG formation in the endoplasmic reticulum. the high HG:LG ratio is highly correlated with the lymphatic metastasis abilities of hepatocarcinoma cell lines (72). the impairment of spatial memory tasks (76, 77) and the inflammation induced by traumatic brain injury (77) suggest a tight relationship between apoD and caveolin 1. apoD internalization is followed by the endocytosis of BSG, leading to the redistribution of BSG. the colocalization of exogenous apoD internalized and basigin suggest that apoD can follow the same endocytosis pathway as basigin for its internalization process. this study is the first to identify BSG, more particularly LG-BSG, as a receptor essential for apoD internalization.
